title: Dale Duesing
text:
Dale Duesing (born September 26, 1947) is an American <a href="baritone">baritone</a>. As an <a href="opera">opera</a> singer, he has had an international career spanning five decades.
Duesing grew up in <a href="Milwaukee">Milwaukee</a>, Wisconsin. He studied <a href="piano">piano</a> throughout childhood, and enrolled at <a href="Lawrence%20University">Lawrence University</a>, majoring in piano performance. He switched to vocal performance while in college, and won the <a href="Metropolitan%20Opera">Metropolitan Opera</a> Competition in his final year of study. After traveling to Europe with a <a href="Fulbright%20Program">Fulbright Scholarship</a>, Duesing made a name for himself there.
Duesing has performed at the Metropolitan Opera, <a href="San%20Francisco%20Opera">San Francisco Opera</a>, <a href="Lyric%20Opera%20of%20Chicago">Lyric Opera of Chicago</a>, <a href="La%20Scala">La Scala</a> (as Arlecchino in "Ariadne auf Naxos", 1984), <a href="Vienna%20State%20Opera">Vienna State Opera</a>, <a href="Paris%20Op%C3%A9ra">Paris Opéra</a>, and <a href="Royal%20Opera%20House">Covent Garden</a>, among others.
He appeared at the Metropolitan from 1979 to 1989 in "Ariadne auf Naxos" (with <a href="Johanna%20Meier">Johanna Meier</a> and <a href="Ren%C3%A9%20Kollo">René Kollo</a>), "Die Zauberflöte" (opposite <a href="Rita%20Shane">Rita Shane</a>, then <a href="Zdzis%C5%82awa%20Donat">Zdzisława Donat</a>, as the Queen of Night), "Pagliacci" (as Silvio, with <a href="Carlo%20Bergonzi%20%28tenor%29">Carlo Bergonzi</a> and <a href="Cornell%20MacNeil">Cornell MacNeil</a>), "Don Pasquale" (directed by <a href="John%20Dexter">John Dexter</a>), "Il barbiere di Siviglia", "Pelléas et Mélisande" (a performance later released on Compact Discs), "Peter Grimes" (as Ned Keene, opposite <a href="Jon%20Vickers">Jon Vickers</a>), "Billy Budd" (with <a href="Richard%20Cassilly">Richard Cassilly</a>, in Dexter's production), and "Die Fledermaus" (as Dr Falke).
In 2020, Mr Duesing was seen as the Forester in "<a href="The%20Cunning%20Little%20Vixen">The Cunning Little Vixen</a>" in The Netherlands.
The baritone has also sung under the direction of <a href="Karl%20B%C3%B6hm">Karl Böhm</a>, <a href="Leonard%20Bernstein">Leonard Bernstein</a>, <a href="James%20Levine">James Levine</a>, <a href="Carlo%20Maria%20Giulini">Carlo Maria Giulini</a>, <a href="Edo%20de%20Waart">Edo de Waart</a>, <a href="Herbert%20von%20Karajan">Herbert von Karajan</a>, and <a href="Seiji%20Ozawa">Seiji Ozawa</a>.
In 1993, Duesing received a <a href="Grammy%20Award">Grammy Award</a> for his 1991 recording of <a href="Samuel%20Barber">Samuel Barber</a>'s "The Lovers" with the <a href="Chicago%20Symphony%20Orchestra">Chicago Symphony Orchestra</a> and was named the Singer of the Year by "<a href="Opernwelt">Opernwelt</a>" magazine in 1994. Duesing made his debut as director at <a href="Opern-%20und%20Schauspielhaus%20Frankfurt">Frankfurt Opera</a> with "<a href="Il%20viaggio%20a%20Reims">Il viaggio a Reims</a>".
Other of his recordings include "Così fan tutte" (conducted by <a href="Bernard%20Haitink">Bernard Haitink</a>, 1986), Hans Zender's "<a href="Stephen%20Climax">Stephen Climax</a>" (with <a href="Ronald%20Hamilton">Ronald Hamilton</a> as St Simeon Stylites, 1990), and "La vie avec un idiot" (conducted by <a href="Mstislav%20Rostropovich">Mstislav Rostropovich</a>, 1992). On DVD are "Wozzeck" (1996) and "Moses und Aron" (2009).
